description:
Dungeons of Daggorath is a dungeon crawler which has rudimentary magic, character building, and combat elements, like a Wizardry-style RPG, while also using a text parser like a graphic adventure. The top part of the screen is dominated by a first-person view of the dungeon, while the player enters his/her commands at the bottom. Verb recognition includes commands such as MOVE, TURN, USE, ATTACK, STOW, and INCANT.

The game contains five levels of dungeon to explore, and more and more powerful monsters the deeper the player character advances. Some monsters of the same type get stronger as well - for example, the troll starts on level one armed with a club, but on later levels he gets more powerful with an axe. Other features include different levels of torches that affect viewing distance and eventually wear out; monsters generating different sounds that grow louder or fainter as they get closer to the protagonist (even if they cannot be seen behind walls); and the real-time aspect of the heartbeat. If the player character is injured or running too fast, his heart rate increases, and he may pass out if the player pushes too far. During that time, monsters would keep moving and attacking.
title: Dungeons of Daggorath

description:
An original game, Panic Button involved one working on a multi-level manufacturing line, trying to keep up orders by assembling various products. The parts drop out of 3 chutes on the top left of the playfield, and you can run all over the place to pick up the 3 different parts of the product, and you have to assemble them in order (for example, a robot must have it's feet on the bottom, torso in the middle, and head on the top). The pieces come out of the first conveyor belt in random order, and you can only carry one piece at a time. If you accidentally assemble a product in the wrong order, it becomes useless, so you have to be careful where you drop the pieces. There is also a Panic Button (hence the game name) in the upper right corner that you can hit that stops the conveyor belts temporarily.

For each level, you have to make a specific amount of the product you are creating within a time limit of 2 minutes, and each successive level gets faster and faster (and you also have to build more and more). Also, since the 3 conveyor belts are staggered, and pieces will drop on their own between them, you have to be careful watching them as they get near a drop point, as they could fall on pieces you have already constructed and potentially screw that particular product up. On later levels, the bad products start bouncing around as well, interfering with your manoeuvring.

sample_screenshots.caption: Intro screen - all the shapes flying around are the products you have to construct
Starting level one - it zooms in each part as it shows you how to construct the robot.
Select your level - remember, the higher the level, the faster the converyor belts move.
Game play level 1 - start making robots!

title: Panic Button

description: Popcorn! is a game based on the 1978 arcade game Avalanche by Atari (which itself spawned the Atari 2600 hit, Kaboom!). In this game, there are popcorn kernels in rows at the top of the screen, and you start with 6 levels of frying pans at the bottom. As the kernels start to fall, you have to catch them before they hit the conveyor belt at the very bottom of the screen. Each time a kernel makes it all the way to the bottom, you lose a frying pan, until you have none left. The higher the level you get into the game, the faster the popcorn falls, and more kernels will fall at once.

sample_screenshots.caption: Popcorn game screen - game just finished.

title: Popcorn!

description:
Z-89 is the Coco 3-exclusive variant of Zaxxon, by the same author (Steve Bjork) who developed the original, officially licensed Datasoft version. This game was released twice (with some slight changes), once when sold by Game Point Software, and then directly by SRB Software after Game Point folded a short time after.

The basic play of Z-89 focuses on the objective to destroy the Zaxxon robot at the end of the two floating space fortresses, while defending yourself from planes, tanks, missiles, and colliding with terrain. You have to keep your fuel topped up as well, by shooting fuel tanks. The game is played in isometric 3D, showing you flying at an angle, where you can fly side to side and up and down (you are always moving forward). Z-89 adds one new twist to Zaxxon: in the space sequence (between the two floating space fortresses), in addition to planes coming after you, you also have meteors to contend with.

sample_screenshots.caption: Flying throught the first fortress... watch out for the wall!
Intro screen for original Game Point Release (version 1.01)

title: Z-89

description: The sequel to Downland, Cave Walker more than doubled the number of playable levels. Also new is a practice mode and a game save feature. Controls and visuals were also improved or enhanced in various ways. New gameplay elements, such as rising/falling platforms were added as well.

sample_screenshots.caption: First chamber - note the blue elevator pads
2nd Credits screen/high scores/Practice or real game?

title: Cave Walker

description: Gold Runner 2000 is an expanded clone of Lode Runner, adding both vertical and horizontal scrolling to the gameplay, as well as password warps to higher levels, and digitized sound effects and music samples. As in Lode Runner, your mission is to steal all of the gold bars, while avoiding the guards, and escape up to the next level after you have gotten them all. Guards can pick up to 1 Gold bar themselves, and the only way to get them back is to dig a self filling hole in the ground (on ground that you can actually dig in) early enough that it kills the guard. If you dig it to late, the guard will crawl out on his own (something you can not do if you get in the same situation). The game takes on strategy and maze play as well, as some of the gold bars are buried inside walls that you have to dig through to get to them.

sample_screenshots.caption: First opening screen - and mentioning "The Challenge"
Part of level 1 (screen scrolls in all 4 directions)
Second opening screen - options, and a jibe at Eric from Chet as part of "The Challenge"

title: Gold Runner 2000

description: The classic board game ported to the home computer. Two players try to move all of their checkers around the board and off by rolling dice, and strategically blocking their opponent.

sample_screenshots.caption: Game screen - there is no title or credit screen

title: Color Backgammon

description:
"They're here!" This game is based on Tobe Hooper's popular 1982 horror movie where the Freeling family occupy a haunted suburban home and their daughter Carol-Anne is abducted by ghosts through the television set. There's three levels of ever-increasing difficulty on your quest to rescue Carol-Anne.

The first level is a top-down view of the neighbourhood where you must search nearby homes for these items: a length of rope, a ribbon, a towel, some tennis balls, and a handkerchief. A black dot on a house indicates where they are and you only have a limited 30 time units to accomplish this. You must avoid speeding cars on the streets by ducking into driveways and avoid the poltergeist who will randomly go from house to house (seen as a flashing box). Once all the items are acquired, you enter the house where the poltergeist lives.

In the second level, you are shown a view of a stairway going upward and on each step there are barriers moving horizontally - squares and ovals with X's through them. You (as a pair of shoe prints) must move up or down, left or right, to avoid all obstacles until you reach the top where the steps get narrower and more difficult. Meanwhile a poltergeist will also be chasing you up the stairs so you must be quick before the 30 time units are up.

In the third and final level, you enter the closet and from a first-person view must shoot a firearm and hit 8 poltergeists but beware as Carol-Anne is also there and if you hit her, you will go all the way back to the first level again. If you manage to complete it, you will receive the message, "This house is clean".

sample_screenshots.caption: Level one done, now on to the stairs
First level - locate items in houses!
I have picked up a red ribbon

title: Poltergeist

description:
FlightSim I puts the player inside the cockpit, behind the controls of a high performance jet. This game is in the conception of the Flight Simulator computer game series but for the TRS-80 Color Computer.

The simulation environment consists of approximately 22,185 square miles and recreates most of the conditions normally encountered in actual flight. The player can fly the jet to any of eight airports or nine landmarks scattered throughout the simulation area.

The Jet features retractable gear, full flap control, and a cruising speed of 375 knots (or 432 mph). Its instrument panel includes Auto-Pilot, Glidescope, Attitude Deviation Indicator (ADI), Altitude, Speed, Rate of Climb indicators.

sample_screenshots.caption: On the runway, preparing for takeoff

title: FlightSim I

description:
Based on Robert A. Heinlein's Hugo-award winning book, Starship Troopers, this game simulates the brief combat life in M.I. (Mobile Infantry) far in the future. The Terran Federation is locked in a deadly war with "the Bugs," and has announced "Operation Bughouse," an attack directly on the Bugs' home world of Klendathu. Equipped with a state-of-the-art power suit, you drop in from orbit and torch as many Bug warriors as possible, then bounce back out before your suit runs out of energy or the Bugs overwhelm you. Survive three drops and you can retire, with pay based on how many Bugs of each rank you blasted.

Game play consists of carefully selecting which block of the drop zone to land in, and then blasting the warrior and queen Bugs as they advance down the screen toward you. For each warrior and queen you might see, however, there are many more harmless worker Bugs, which look exactly like the warriors. They're all swarming toward you; choose your targets carefully and don't waste your ammo. You'll know the warriors because they're the ones shooting at you.

sample_screenshots.caption: Get ready for the first drop
In the two player variation the second player is a square

title: Klendathu

description: This is a ROM cartridge game which puts you in command of a starship, looking into outerspace through the forward "viewscreen." With each hand on a joystick, you dodge and blast enemy Scouts and Battle Cruisers bent on your destruction. You can switch your view to radar, detecting ships too far away to see in your viewscreen, and both the viewscreen and radar can be zoomed in and out. Your ship's shield protects you from collisions and enemy fire; when it's gone, so are you.
title: Quasar Commander

description:
Lord Scylla, ruler of six galaxies, has declared eminent domain over ours. Zycon, the commandant of Scylla's Imperial Fleet, has already conquered or annihilated all human outposts and colonies, and recommends immediate surrender, tribute, and the submission of some representatives as laboratory specimens.

Standing in Zycon's way is your fast, deadly ship and skills as a pilot. This ROM cartridge game puts a joystick in each of your hands, and an Ion engine, hyper-drive, and twin Masor cannons at your command. The game screen provides a view looking forward out of your craft, two Short Range Sensors showing incoming enemies ahead and behind you, and a power meter. Each hit by an enemy blast reduces your power and briefly scrambles your view. Four levels of play culminate in a campaign where you jump from sector to sector eradicating enemy ships in dogfights with up to four opponents. A Long Range Sensor screen shows the status of your ship's various systems, how many enemies are in each sector, and where to find space stations. To be recharged and repaired, you carefully maneuver your ship to the correct position and speed to receive a power pack from the space station.
title: Project Nebula

description:
You are trapped in a maze of electrified walls and deadly mechanical monsters programmed by an evil scientist to kill intruders. Collect the gold that was stolen from you, dodge laser pellets shot by the monsters, and blast a few of them in return.

In this ROM cartridge game you maneuver a figure through simple "mazes," exiting by a doorway on any of the sides you did not start on, which puts you in another such maze and gives you another "man." On the way, you must out-maneuver monsters who become increasingly aggressive with each maze and shortly start shooting at you. You can maneuver the monsters into walls or each other, or just shoot them. Grabbing the treasure will help your score along, too. The game does not actually offer escape from the maze; the best you can hope for is vengeance and a high score.

At first glance your perspective is top-down, looking down at the walls of the maze, but your man, the monsters, and the treasure, are all shown from the side.

sample_screenshots.caption: Each screen has a different maze
Some mazes have more enemies than others

title: Monster Maze

description:
As a merchant in the distant future, you captain a starship from system to system, visiting starports to buy and sell cargo until you amass one thousand credits and retire to the quiet life. Fuel, upkeep, and even computer access contribute to overhead expenses. Pirates will get in your way and do costly damage to your ship or even end your career if your aim is slow. When money runs short, however, you can always scoop fuel from a red giant star or swipe some cargo from the ship a few bays down. If you make your deliveries on time, your reputation will bring you better fees.

The emphasis of the game is economic; ship-to-ship combat is purely a gallery shoot with moving targets and a possibility of escape. All play is real-time, so even in the starport, your fuel is being used and delivery dates are getting closer. Care must be taken in selecting cargo, as some runs will lose you money for the amount of fuel they consume. Run out of fuel in mid-jump and you're space salvage. Everything happens on one, tripartite game screen showing the view outside your ship, your status (cash, fuel, repair, date, etc.), and the graphical menu below.

sample_screenshots.caption: When you enter orbit there may be several nearby locations you can thrust to
Starting the game in a starport
Starting the game; choose a skill level

title: Star Trader

description:
Bustout is somewhat of a derivative work based on the classic Breakout style games. The bricks in Bustout are located to the right of the player in colored rows.

It allows you and three other players to play in turn. Options for gameplay setup include the number of balls (1‐20) and gravity. If you select gravity mode, you have to make upward paddle motions as you strike the ball if you want it to rise high enough to hit the bricks.
title: Bustout

description:
Football for the Color Computer is your normal American style game. It allows players to pick offense/defense plays along with punt and passing.

The game is two-player, and each player controls a single footballer of your five-man team during the down. Each person uses a joystick to select plays and control the footballer. If you reach the end zone, the athlete dances and spikes the football.

sample_screenshots.caption: Each player needs to select a play

title: Football

description:
Dino Wars is an arcade-style fast-action game, where the two players (there is no single player mode) control two battling dinosaurs via joystick control. Each player tries to position his Dino in front or behind the other for a quick roaring bite attack for a knock down, reducing the score of the other player's Dino by 20 points.

The playing field scrolls to the left and right, but also contains some depth of field, both near and far. This allows for dodging to avoid your opponent’s parallel attack. Once you have successfully reduced your opponent's score to zero, his Dino will run off into the distance yelping due to his wounds.
title: Dino Wars

description:
Pegasus and the Phantom Riders is a derivative work of the arcade classic Joust. The player rides the white winged horse Pegasus from Greek mythology. Players must approach the Phantom Riders just above, so that Pegasus can use his hooves to destroy them. They will fall from the sky and, if they land on the ground below, a cross grave marker will appear. If players leave the grave marker undisturbed it will turn into a carnivorous plant and revive the rider to fight again.

The game has three phases with multiple waves of Phantom Riders that must be defeated before moving onto the next level, taking the player closer to the phantom island. The game features a quasi-3D effect that all of the Phantom Riders fly in from the distant phantom island. As players proceed through levels, they get closer to the island. The last level has several dangers; Phantom Riders, fireballs, carnivorous plants, or drowning if Pegasus falls into the sea. The game allows for 1 or 2 players with duel and cooperative modes.

sample_screenshots.caption: Making sure the Phantoms don't return by destroying the graves
Phase 1 start phantom island in distance
Phase 2 start getting closer to phantom island

title: Pegasus and the Phantom Riders

description:
Three submarines, endless missiles raining down. How long can you protect your islands by firing interceptor missiles? Defeat is inevitable, as the incoming missiles increase in speed and density. Some will suddenly split into multiple warheads targeting multiple islands, and if you survive long enough, the smart bombs will come out, capable of evading your interceptors. Your only advantages are the broad, area effect of your missiles, replacement islands awarded as your score races upward, and the lightning-fast, hand-eye coordination given by your ancestors just for playing video games like this one.

A ROM cartridge, Polaris presents the standard elevation view of a Missile Command game, placing three submarines among six islands. Islands and submarines alike are targeted by missiles dropping from the top of the screen; destroyed subs come back the next round, and islands are replaced every 2000 points. Points are awarded for surviving islands, submarines, and interceptor missiles, multiplied by the level's difficulty. Interesting effects include color set changes which can camouflage incoming missiles, explosions which endure in mid-air as additional missiles reach the area, and explosions which wrap around from one edge of the screen to the other.

Hot-seat, two-player play is possible, split by round with competing scores shown at the top of the screen. The manual even makes tongue-in-cheek mention that the scores can be targeted and blown up, but to no effect.

sample_screenshots.caption: Round three - two islands are gone
Color switches each round - points are 2x
Smart bomb avoids my missiles - destroys island

title: Polaris

description:
This ROM cartridge game provides a strategically faithful reproduction of the centuries-old game, Gomoku, and its newer variant, Renju. The colors of the board and pieces are not traditional, and the interface is simple, but the cartridge stores 78 variations of the traditional "book openings", including sequences well past the first few moves of the game. Further, it can selectively adhere to the complex strictures of Renju, prohibiting 24 opening moves and certain winning patterns any time during the game.

The object of both games is to place five of your pieces in a row on a square, 15x15 board, with each player taking turns. In this implementation, the board can be reduced as small as 9x9. When playing against the computer, you can choose from eight levels of difficulty, move first or second (which defines your play in both games), switch sides, get a hint, take back any number of moves, review an entire game step-by-step, and watch the computer "think" or even play itself. Play against another human is possible, too, but the opening-move restrictions of Renju are left to you to enforce.
title: Gomoku / Renju

description:
The latest breakthrough in nuclear power is broken. It's the network, of course. In the dazzling future of the late 1990's, the world's first fusion reactor is online: energy particles are shooting out of emission tubes toward the energy posts... and missing. As each one passes the posts and strikes another tube on the opposite side of the core, the reactor moves one step closer to meltdown. The reflectoid is there; that's the solid energy deflection device which bounces the particles into the posts. It's supposed be remotely controlled by a sophisticated network of computers, but tonight it has to be controlled by you!

Reactoid gives you a top-down view of the reactor core, the heart of Professor Albert Arnstein's experimental and top-secret power station. Twenty-four energy posts are at the center, surrounded by twenty particle emission tubes, any one of which could emit the next energy particle. You generate kilowatts (your score) by deflecting the particle into a post as it passes one. There's only one chance to get it right; after the first bounce off the reflectoid, the particle will just pass through it on a second attempt. If seven of those particles find their way to another emission tube, whether by shooting across the core undeflected or by your inept deflection, meltdown is reached. On the other hand, if you deflect particles into all of the posts, lighting them, you survive the round and are rewarded with a fresh start and two particles shooting across the core at a time. For each round you survive, the particles on the screen and the kilowatt multiplier increase. Three meltdowns and you're done, unless you've picked up a spare reflectoid along the way.

sample_screenshots.caption: Title - Flying animated letters spell the title
Some particles deflected - only 2 letters left then meltdown

title: Reactoid

description:
Your job: archaeologist for Galactic Council of Worlds. Your mission: travel to the desert planet of Roloc and investigate the Temple of ROM. Your equipment: a scroll (which contains instructions from the game's manual) and a laser.

Two missions have gone before you. Technology has improved since then, allowing electronic scans of the temple structure. It is a maze, and there is activity. Two million years ago a society steeped in wealth and the magic occupied the planet. Legend has it that they left behind a curse protecting their temples and the valuable artifacts contained within. Your purpose is "to enrich the present by expanding our knowledge of the experiences and achievements of this past civilization."

In game terms, this means blasting monsters and collecting treasure. Poisonous spiders and sentient fireballs occupy the rooms of the temple, while giant bats patrol overhead, swooping down when they spot you. Enticing you onward are golden cups, jade crosses, diamond rings, crystal goblets, and silver pitchers. Magical treasures such as crystal balls and golden crowns will for a time render you invisible and boost your laser, respectively.

No small challenge is the maze itself, eerily reminiscent of a colossal computer chip. You have an overhead view, but only of a small portion, and it doesn't scroll until you're near the edge. The result is that while moving into new territory, you see only a half-dozen paces ahead. There are a few pairs of transfer portals, which will zap you across the maze, but as often with archeology, your investigation relies on legwork. The maze, occupants, and treasures are constant each play, so over time you can come to know the temple well, and your laser very well.

sample_screenshots.caption: Clearing room on left - next chambers have spiders
Using laser on a poisonous spider

title: Temple of Rom

description:
This ROM cartridge game challenges the player to draw circles around objects which pop up on the screen.

Your joystick steers the head of a constantly moving line segment, which by circling it back upon itself, you can make into a loop. Capture an object within that loop, and you score points. Objects continue to appear on the screen, and stay until you circle them. Capture more than one object in the same loop and your reward is multiplied.

The difficulty of the game is in avoiding the objects. Your line segment can run into itself and the edge of the map, but not one of the objects you're trying to circle. That ends your turn. Play becomes a trick of turning tighter and tighter circles to capture objects before they disappear, but not too tightly as to run into them. You can vary your speed, and correspondingly the length of your line segment, by the distance your joystick is from its center. The result is that at maximum speed and length, your line turns widely.

Further increasing the challenge is that the objects move. Apples and cherries are nice and stationary, but the magnets drift slowly. The roller skates skate. Then the yo-yo's appear, doing what yo-yo's do. Timing becomes important. The final complication is the skulls. They're worth no points and they don't go away until you crash. You just have to dodge them and keep circling the moving objects. Hot seat play for two players is possible, giving you the opportunity to laugh at someone else for their inability to draw a circle.

sample_screenshots.caption: Circle objects with blue line for points

title: Doubleback

description:
Pertascii is a multiplayer client/server word game for the Tandy Color Computer running the OS9 operating system.

The game is played in rounds. Each player receives the same set of ten to thirteen letters, and forms words of three or more letters. At the end of each round, the game eliminates all words formed by two or more players, and allows players to challenge each others words. Pertascii scores the remaining words based on word length, and another round begins. The first player to reach a predetermined score wins.
title: Pertascii

description:
Dragon Blade is titled after the object the player needs to find in order to save a medieval village from the terror of a dragon. The creature killed the village's chief during it's last attack, and now it's up to his son to succeed him. Beginning his quest in the Forest of Lore, the protagonist must explore the countryside, finding and using items to progress in his quest, while he encounters hostile as well as helpful creatures, such as a witch during his journey.

Some of the graphics are animated. The parser is of the standard verb noun type. The possible directions for movement are shown and entered on screen as single letters (like N for North).

sample_screenshots.caption: Not the most original kind of person I would say, but at least she helps me out.

title: Dragon Blade

description:
Biosphere can be seen as some sort of precursor to the more known Maxis game SimLife. The player assumes the role of captain and ecologist on the starship Arkworld, the task is the survival of a colony of (randomized) alien lifeforms on a newly discovered planet. To fulfill it, animals and plants from the Arkworld's cargo hold can be added, with the goal to create a functioning, self-supporting ecosystem.

By using the icon-driven interface, the environment as well as traits of the native colony and the species on board the ship can be examined. Various factors, such as the atmospheric elements that are expelled/inhaled and food habits play a role. The Arkworld contains two hundred species of animals and plants of randomized quantity, and there is also a limited option of genetic engineering, that may not necessarily produce the desired characteristics. To make the simulation run it's course, the integrated time-control is locked into hypertime mode. The game will then run until all native animals are perished or the stability of the created ecology is proven for sixty-five thousand days. A save option is included.

sample_screenshots.caption: Four different color modes are available, here is the plant manifest screen where the available plant lifeforms on the ship are shown
The "window view" allows a look at the animals and plants on the planet
Another view with different color mode

title: Biosphere

description:
If it can be said that the Cold War and computers grew up together, Wargame captures them in their maturity. Wargame simulates a massive defense computer launching intercontinental nuclear missiles. The game was inspired by "WarGames," an American movie of the same year which starts with a young hacker war-dialing to swipe a new game for his home computer, and ends reflecting the period's very real distrust of computers and defense systems.

Wargame presents the global view screen of NORAD's missile defense system, as envisioned by the movie. Missiles trace lines between ten American bases and ten Soviet bases, bright white circles blotting out the city on the receiving end. The object is to destroy the Soviet bases before all the American ones are gone, which takes five to ten minutes, the span often predicted in the 1980's for World War III.

Commands are issued by typing fast, until the Soviets jam your launch codes, but you can recover and return the favor. Enemy subs require targeting, when you can find the time to detect them, and if you're really ahead of schedule, you can check base status on either side. Since missiles fly only one at a time, and computer responses eat precious seconds, victory mostly lies in efficient typing and remembering which bases you have left to launch from. Win or lose, the futility of trading the business ends of nuclear missiles is always clear.

sample_screenshots.caption: Game over last base destroyed - Soviets win

title: Wargame

description:
The Rainbow magazine, compiled a collection of text and graphical adventures programmed in BASIC. The default interface of early 1980's microcomputers, BASIC was familiar to every owner. Most of the 108-page manual is listings of BASIC code for each game; the challenge of programming in such a small space is a unifying theme. A couple, like "The Door," fit into just four kilobytes, matching the total RAM of one retailed Color Computer model. "The Door" spoofs the universal frustration of all but a few '80's text adventures: figuring out how to tell the game what you wanted to do was often more difficult than knowing what to do. The games herein offer few exceptions to that rule, but the contributors, both amateur and professional developers, take the player to the limits of earth and outer space. Most of the background color and storyline are contained in the manual's introduction or the first screen of the game.

Polynesia, Africa, the house down the street, the evil side of the universe, and even a dream provide settings. Two adventures show overhead views of your circumstance, but the rest rely on text to be your eyes and ears. Two-word responses at a command line prompt are typically all you need to unlock the mysteries.

  • Polynesian Adventure: Hunt for treasure in the South Seas.
  • Horror House: Slaughter the computer's minions to prove you're no chicken.
  • Search for the Ruby Chalice: Explore the wilds of Africa to find the world's most precious treasure.
  • Lighthouse Adventure: Finding the legendary pirate treasure is only half the challenge.
  • Dungeon Adventure: You get sidekicks, wandering monsters, and even a town in this dungeon-crawl RPG.
  • Sir Randolph of the MoorsSir Randolph of the Moors: From rags to riches, a kid finds a sword and becomes a hero.
  • Dreamer: The program limits of four kilobytes of RAM make wandering through this dream appropriately Kafkaesque.
  • One Room: Blinfolded and tied up, all you have to do is get out.
  • The Door: How quickly and how many of the 44 ways can you find to open it?
  • Dr. Avaloe: The new job: Find your way through the mad scientist's deadly rooms.
  • The Deed of the York: Brave the macabre traps left for you by your grandfather to inherit his fortune.
  • Dungeon: Endure the maze of caverns to rescue the sweet princess from the despicable Groms.
  • An Unexplored Mansion: Setting out on your own, the adventure you find is a mysterious old mansion.
  • Escape from Sparta: Preserve freedom in the universe by rescuing the creator of your robotic race.
title: The Rainbow Book of Adventures

description:
Adventures #1 is a compilation of adventures published in the CLOAD cassette magazine, namely:

  • Jerusalem Adventure
  • Ultimate Adventure
  • Williamsburg Adventure
  • House Adventure
  • Andrea Doria Adventure
  • Blackard's Castle
  • Realm of Nauga
title: SilverWare Adventures #1

description:
The CoCo version of Tetris is one of many conversions of the famous block-stacking game. The goal is to place pieces made up of four tiles in a ten-by-twenty well, organizing them into complete rows, which then disappear. As rows are cleared, the pace of the game increases, and the game ends if the stack reaches the top of the well.

Options of the CoCo version include the selection of starting level (between 0 and 9) and a handicap setting, allowing to pre-fill the well with blocks in seven different levels. The playing level can be increased at any time and a preview of the next piece to appear can be toggled on and off. Scoring works similarly to the original PC version of the game as written by Vadim Gerasimov: there are more points the higher a piece is dropped, a bonus for not displaying the next piece and a bonus for playing in higher levels/difficulties. No points are given for clearing rows and there is no high score table.

Implemented as a 'fat binary', the game offers a higher resolution mode on a CoCo 3. Besides displaying more of the Saint Basil's Cathedral-inspired background graphic, the CoCo 3 version allows to optionally display a keyboard command overview, the current level and a pieces statistic.
title: Tetris

description: Zaksund is a space/shooter game designed to be a clone of the arcade game Zaxxon. The game is played from an isometric view where the player controls a small spaceship. The player's task is to avoid obstacles including missiles, walls, and enemy spaceships. The player is able to shoot a small projectile to take out enemies. Levels become progressively faster and more difficult as the game progresses.
title: Zaksund

description: Intracolor Grand Prix is a racing game similar to Pole Position. The player races a Formula 1 car from a third person perspective and can do so on five different tracks. Each race consists of five laps and the objective is to simply get the best time possible. At the same time other cars have to be avoided since crashing three times in the same race leads to game over. Upon completing a race the game automatically progresses to the next track. The game can be played with joystick or keyboard and features manual transmission with a single button used to switch between low and high gear.
title: Intracolor Grand Prix

description:
Zenix is a shoot 'em up that resembles Galaga albeit without the capture feature from that game. The enemies are invading insects that start out swarming around the screen before taking their positions above the player. At times groups of bugs leave the formation and attempt to crash into the player who can freely move (including up and down) around the bottom third of the screen. The bugs have different colours which indicates their level of armour. Those with a higher armour level require multiple hits to take down unless the player has access to armour piercing bullets.

Unlike other shooters of its kind there is no life system. Instead there is a fuel meter that decreases when the ship is hit. Some of the enemies are fuel bugs. When these are hit they turn into a solid color and slowly drifts toward the bottom. These should be picked up since they refill some of the fuel and sometimes they also give an upgrade to the ship's weaponry. Weapon upgrades include armour piercing bullets and bullets splitting in three directions.

In total there are 32 levels with increasing difficulty due to higher pace and more dangerous enemies. This includes monster bugs which instantly kills the player upon contact even if there is fuel is left. After every fourth level there is a bonus stage which allows the player to gain bonus points and consists of four waves of enemies that fly across the screen but that does not attack the player.
title: Zenix

description: Moby Maths is an educational game teaching the four elementary arithmetic operators: addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. When starting out any of the operators can be selected along with difficulty level, pace of the game and number of questions. The game screen consists of a whale on the right and a math problem to the left. Beneath the problem fishes with an answer will appear one at a time and swim towards the whale. If the fish's answer is correct the player has to press the space bar to eat it. If it is not correct the player should let it pass. The game then goes on until the player has answered a predefined number of questions.
title: Moby Maths

description:
An unauthorized version of Donkey Kong. This version of the game is faithful to the arcade version as it contains all the levels and intermissions from it.

The game has a configuration screen where the player can set the number of lives they start with, at what score intervals a bonus life is given, level of difficulty, the region as that effects the order of the levels, the palette type, and whether to have the sound on or off.

sample_screenshots.caption: Game configuration screen - combines arcade DIP switch settings with Coco specific options

title: Donkey Kong

description: Stellar Life Line is a side scrolling shoot 'em up where the player's task is to escort a fleet of space ships from one star base to another. The game is similar to Defender with the player being able to move both back and forth and having a scanner showing the locations of ships and obstacles. There are three different obstacles (asteroids, magnetic mines and alien ships) that the player has to shoot down since any collision will lead to a loss of one of the fleet ship. The fleet ships are also destroyed when running out of fuel which happens as they are hit by enemy fire. Refuelling is possible by manoeuvring the player's ship over one of the ships in the fleet. Some attackers can attach itself to a fleet ship to do a sneak attack and steal the ship.

sample_screenshots.caption: Reaching the base which is represented by a simple line

title: Stellar Life Line

description: Those Darn Marbles! is a Marble Madness variant. Like the original arcade game it involves moving a marble across isometric levels with the goal of reaching an exit point. Monsters, traps and long drops can stop the marble's progression but there is no limit on how many times the marble can be destroyed. The only way to fail with the game is by running out of time before reaching the ext. Extra speed can be gained by holding down the fire button which doubles the amount of acceleration. There are three different monsters: marble munchers which confuse the marble, acid pools which dissolves the marble into a pile of scunge and jehosaphats which cause the marble to perform an unintended action. Scoring is based on the number of squares rolled over and extra points are given when there is time left on the clock.
title: Those Darn Marbles!

description: Androne is a maze based first person shoot 'em up. It takes place in a computer that has been overrun by data bugs. The player controls a robot that enters the system in an attempt to kill off all the bugs. Each level is a maze with a number of bugs that all have to be killed. The game is played with joystick that allow the player to wander through the corridors of the maze. When encountering enemies the player shoots by holding down the fire button and uses the stick to move the cursor around. Getting hit leads to the robot's energy being absorbed but it can recharged by locating and shooting power units. If the energy decreases to zero the game ends. Once a level has been completed an elevator exit will open and the player can move on to the next level.
title: Androne

description:
Ghana Bwana is an arcade action game with isometric graphics similar to the arcade game Congo Bongo. The game is set on a fictitious African island and is made up of nine levels, some scrolling and some fixed, with the objective of the seven first being to collect all the pieces of a treasure map. The levels are timed and all pieces have to be collected before the time runs out.

In the first level the player is seated in a canoe going down a river while later levels are on foot. The levels on foot allow the player to jump which is necessary in the non-scrolling levels for leaping between islands without landing in water. There are some perils to watch out for like moving objects and natives called guardians that throw spears. Some items can be picked up including a bow for shooting the guardians and a golden key which can be used to open a treasure chest which gives an extra life. In the eight level the aim is to get to a balloon and escape while in the final level the balloon is shot down and the player returns to the first scene and begins a new round of the game.

sample_screenshots.caption: After climbing the waterfall the guardian can be killed with bow

title: Ghana Bwana

description: Color Cubes is a computer adaptation of the puzzle game Rubik's Cube. Like in the original game the cube is made up of 27 smaller cubes (called cubies) of six different colours and the aim is to rotate the slices so that each face is made up of a solid color. The cube is isometrically drawn and the player uses keyboard controls to roll the slices. While working on the cube it is possible to undo and redo up to 255 moves. A reset cube option allows the player to see how a particular cube is constructed and it's also possible to create custom cube configurations. There is also an option to use tapes to save and load games.
title: Color Cubes

description: Spidercide is a shoot 'em up game where the player has ended up on a planet inhabited by enormous spiders. The game is played from a top down perspective with controls similar to Asteroids where the player's task is simply to shoot down the spiders before getting killed. As the spiders move around the screen they leave a trail of web that can trap the player. It is possible to shoot through it but each shot will only clear a small part of it. There are two different spiders, slow and fast, and both can weave straight or jagged webs. It's necessary to be extra careful with the ones producing jagged webs since they will seek out and chase the player. Any contact with a spider leads to a life being lost. There are three lives but extra ones are given upon reaching 1000 points.
title: Spidercide

description: Skiing is an alpine skiing game played from a first-person perspective. The aim of the game is simply to ski down a slope (which is randomly generated) and reach the finish banner in the shortest time without missing any gates or going off the piste. If a gate is missing or the skier veers off the piste, the time will not be recorded but the player is allowed to keep skiing. The game is played with a joystick and it is possible to choose between simple and complex controls. Simple controls involve using the stick to steer and speed up. With complex controls the button is used to simulate ski poles with speed being gained with each button press. The speed is then also affected by hills, slopes and moguls and the skier will slow down when making turns, especially sharp turns.
title: Skiing

description: Chopper Strike is a side scrolling shoot 'em up that is similar to Konami's arcade games Scramble and Super Cobra. The player is in control of a helicopter flying over a mountainous terrain where hostile gun turrets, rockets, oil tanks and ICBM's are placed. On the ground there are also blue men that the player can pick up by flying over them. The helicopter's only weapons are missiles whose direction the player can steer by pulling the joystick up and down. The game is made up of one large level where the player simply has to try and stay alive as long as possible. A life is lost when hit by an enemy projectile but also when accidentally killing one of the blue men.

sample_screenshots.caption: Trying to avoid the turret's fire

title: Chopper Strike

description: La Belle Lucie is a solitaire card game. The aim of the game is to move all cards from the tableau onto four foundations located at the top of the screen. The tableau is made up of seventeen groups of three cards and one with just a single card. Only the top card can be picked up and moved to another pile and it has to be of the same suit and at one lower than the card it is played onto. When adding cards to the foundations the player has to start with an ace and then add the 2 and the other cards in the suit in order until the king has been added. After the game has started it is possible to shuffle the cards but only twice. After the shuffles have been used a cheat move called The Merci will become available. It allows the player to pull any card regardless of position and add it to a foundation but it can only be used once.

sample_screenshots.caption: After two shuffles the merci option becomes available

title: La Belle Lucie

description:
The Contras is a platform shooter based on the arcade game Contra. The main difference from the original Contra is that the whole game is played from a side view and that it lacks the behind view 3D stages. There are also differences in level design. While the first level is largely identical to the original game later levels are original.

The basic gameplay is like the original game with the player moving from the left to right while killing all the enemies and destroying all turrets and other obstacles. While standing up it is possible to move and shoot in any of the eight directions (except down) while when lying down it is only possible to shoot forward. Destroying certain items leads to power ups called Falcons appearing and if the player collects them bonus points and weapons upgrades are given. Unlike the original game there is only one weapon upgrade: rapid fire.

The game can be played by two players at the same time. The player that first loses all lives can steal one from the other player and keep playing. When both are out of lives an end screen appears and it's possible to continue at the beginning of the current level at a score of zero, but it can only be done three times.
title: The Contras

description:
Daleks, Cybermen, Mutants, Space Pirates, Robots, Chronon, and the Master have all teamed up to prevent The Doctor from acquiring the 7 parts to the Key of Time! You are The Doctor, and you must operate the controls of the TARDIS.

An unlicensed game based on the BBC Doctor Who series. The player moves the TARDIS through space to land on alien planets. A space map helps guide the player to the planets. Arriving at a planet, the player must avoid incoming enemy ships by moving to the left or right. Each hit, the player takes damage and loses fuel. After surviving a section, 1 key is earned. It was written in BASIC.

There are 9 levels of difficulty.
title: Dr. Who

description:
Varloc is a chess-like strategy game with some similarities to Archon: The Light and the Dark. The game takes place on a board consisting of 64 squares where the player competes against a computer controlled evil wizard called Varloc. On each side there are sixteen warriors: a witch, a sorcerer's apprentice, a minotaur, two archers, two knights, four dwarfs and four trolls. Like in chess each warrior is only allowed certain moves. To win the game it is necessary to defeat the enemy's wizard. If the player manages to find a hidden gem, it is possible to kill Varloc with a single hit.

When two warriors clash on the board the game moves to a battlefield where the player has to defeat Varloc's warrior in a one-on-one duel. Unlike the battles of Archon, the game uses wireframe 3D graphics displayed from a first person perspective. Each warrior has its own way of attacking and defending. The minotaur rams into opponents while knights attack with a sword and can defend with a shield. Dwarfs can disappear at will while the wizard, the witch and the apprentice can shapeshift into three deadly animals: bat, snake or spider. The wizard can also turn into any of the other warriors.

sample_screenshots.caption: Wizard can turn into any of the warriors
Archer shooting arrow at the knight

title: Varloc

description:
Taxi is a driving game where the player takes on the role of a taxi driver. As can be expected the game is about picking up and delivering passengers. The game contains six cities (Dallas, New York, San Francisco, London, Paris and Shanghai) each which is a single screen level played from a top down perspective. As a passenger appears the player uses the joystick to drive to it and pulls up to the curb to pick it up. It's destination will then appear as a cross on the map and the player has to drive there. Each delivered passenger gives a fare and a tip. Driving directly to the destination leads to a big tip while taking a detour leads to a smaller one. When driving it's necessary to watch out for red lights. Driving past one leads to a fine and the passenger will be lost.

The game can be played by two players who then have to cooperate in gaining money for the company.

sample_screenshots.caption: About to pick up a passenger

title: Taxi

description:
Sailor Man is a variant of the arcade game Popeye. This version of the game features largely identical gameplay and contains all three levels from the original game. The player's task is to collect the items dropped by the woman that in this version is called Elsie and not Olive Oyl. In the first level they are hearts, in the second notes and in the third letters making out the word HELP. At the same time it is necessary to avoid Bigfatbadguy who is pursuing the player as well as Olduglyseawoman who throws bottles. These have to be either avoided or punched. Bigfatbadguy can only be taken out for a short while by hitting a punching bag so that a bucket falls down on his head. On all screens it is possible to eat a can of collard greens to gain extra speed, strength and agility which allows the player to knock out Bigfatbadguy.

The game can be customized from an options screen. It is possible to select which screen each player starts at, the number of lives as well as the difficulty level. There is also an invisible screen mode where all of the background graphics (including platforms and ladders) disappear.
title: Sailor Man

description:
Color Baseball is an adaptation of the sport for one or two players who compete in single matches between unnamed red and blue teams. It is possible to assign a name and a batting average for each athlete in both teams.

When the team is up to bat the player controls the batter's swing and can make a base runner steal or slide into a base by using the joystick. It is possible to switch from a right handed batter to a left handed. Swinging is done by pressing the button and the power is decided by up-down position of the joystick. When running the player is always in control of the lead base runner.

When on the field, the player controls both the pitcher and all the other players. Different pitches can be done by pulling the joystick in different directions. For example a downward pull leads to a fast pitch while a diagonal downward pull leads to a curved ball. When the ball is in the air control is automatically given to the fielder that is closest to it. Once the ball has been caught the joystick is used to choose which player to throw it to.

sample_screenshots.caption: Name and batting average can be entered for each player

title: Color Baseball

description: Froggie is an unlicensed clone of the arcade game Frogger, which also had an official release on the TRS-80 Color Computer. It follows the same formula where the player controls a frog which has to cross over five lanes of traffic and five floating objects in a river to reach home. This game is able to take advantage of the Tandy Sound & Speech Cartridge, if present. The player initially starts on "Screen 1", and progresses through levels where the hazards move faster and additional hazards are introduced. The game was developed in Australia.
title: Froggie

description: The evil Sinistaars have invaded the galaxy and it falls to you to destroy them. These fiends will attempt to hold you with a constant barrage of drone ships while they muster their strength and eventually find and obliterate you. Your mission is to mine the myriad of asteroids in search of the precious ore which can be refined into sinibombs, your only weapon against the Sinistaars. Many surprises await as you advance through the increasingly difficult stages.
title: Sinistaar

description: In Fire Copter, the player controls a helicopter armed with both lasers and water cannons. 1-player and 2-player games are available, with players taking alternative helicopter control. The player scrolls over a 3-dimensional wireframe city, looking for active fires. The player needs to position the copter over the center of the fire to spray water cannons to put out the fire. In addition, fire starting androids are present throughout the city, which need to be shot with the copter's laser cannons. The player receives points for fires put out and androids destroyed. As fire spreads, the city is in critical danger, and the player loses a life when too much of the city is engulfed in flame. The player has a total of 3 lives, and when all are lost it's game over. The fire has been quelled at the start of each life, and the city begins to burn anew.

sample_screenshots.caption: Trying to Put Out a Fire

title: Fire Copter

description: The Magic of Zanth is a text adventure with graphics based, most likely unofficially, on Piers Anthony's Xanth universe - more specifically, the second book in the series entitled The Source of Magic. The plot seems to follow that book very closely. King Trent has sent you, Chester Centaur, and Crombie the Soldier (transformed into a griffin) to find the source of magic. So are you Bink then?
title: The Magic of Zanth

description: White Fire of Eternity is a text adventure with graphics with a fantasy theme. You are a 17 year old living in the village of Faernorn, an apprentice to the Clerics of Vor. When the clerics won't explain the identity of the God of White Fire who protects the village, you storm out angrily, accidentally stumble into the Forbidden Wood, and become lost. This is where the quest begins.
title: White Fire of Eternity

description: Hall of the King is a text adventure with graphics that seems to be based on Tolkien's "The Hobbit". You are a prominent adventurer whose aid has been requested by Borodin the dwarf to help recover the legendary "Earthstone", which the dwarves had to abandon when their mountain home was invaded.
title: Hall of the King

alternate_titles.title: Hall of the King II: The Inner Chambers - Two Disk Graphic Adventure for the TRS-80 Color Computer

description: Hall of the King II: The Inner Chambers is the sequel to Hall of the King, and like its predecessor, is a text adventure with graphics. When you reached Firrhest, the Dwarves' mountain home, on your quest to recover the Earthstone, you discovered a strange poem and an old parchment, and the first of three key pieces. You used these to gain access into "The Inner Chambers", where the quest continues.

sample_screenshots.caption: A Giant Golem Guards a Chest

title: Hall of the King II: The Inner Chambers

description: Hall of the King III: The Earthstone Revealed is the third and final game in the Hall of the King series by Glen Dahlgren. Like the first two entries, it is a text adventure with graphics. You have entered the mountain of Firrhest, the dwarves' ancient home, to recover the lost Earthstone, and have found many remnants of the once-great Dwarven civilization. Now, you have finally reached the caldera of the mountain, the heart of Firrhest, where your quest will conclude.
title: Hall of the King III: The Earthstone Revealed

description: In Quest of the Star Lord is a text adventure game with graphics that takes place in a post-apocalyptic future. You are the son of a famous scientist who was sentenced to a work camp after science was branded taboo in the aftermath of the Interworld War. You have been forced to research advanced weaponry for warlords. In your studies, you found reference to an ultimate weapon that used to exist known as the Phoenix Crossbow. You decide to search for this weapon in order to achieve power in this new order.
title: In Quest of the Star Lord

description:
The Interbank Incident is a graphical adventure game for the TRS-80 COCO.

It started at the Interbank Corporation headquarters in New York. It seemed like simple burglary at first. A couple of drawers forced open, some petty cash stolen. Fortunately, a security guard noticed that the "burglar" had shut off the Main Vault Security System for 45 seconds. That's when they discovered The Code Book to control the top secret experimental satellite codenamed Nebulous Project had been stolen.

The player can choose from 7 possible characters, each with their individual strengths and weaknesses. Gameplay is entirely mouse or joystick driven, where the player has the options to take an item, examine an item, use an item, talk to a person, or move to a different area. The goal is to find the thief that stole the code book and save the satellite.
title: The Interbank Incident

description:
The Rainbow Book of Simulations is a book and accompanying cassette tape that was published by the folks behind Rainbow Magazine. The magazine solicited submissions of new simulation programs for the TRS-80 CoCo written in BASIC, and published the best ones in this compilation. The book contains program descriptions and code listings, while the tape can be used to directly load the games onto a TRS-80 Color Computer.

The compilation contains 20 simulation games, among them simulations of the Civil War, sailing, the US Congress, and model rocketry.
title: The Rainbow Book of Simulations

description:
Grover's Number Rover is an educational game for the TRS-CoCo.

Contains mini-games to help young players learn their numbers. Help Grover collect the Twiddlebugs.

  • Twiddle Adding: Add the numbers on Grover's Machine.
  • Twiddle Away: Subtract the numbers on Grover's Machine.
  • Twiddle Counting: Count the Twiddlebugs on the screen.
  • Twiddle Numbers: Press the number displayed on Grover's machine
  • Twiddle Play: Move the Twiddlebug around.
  • Twiddle Windows: Pick up the Twiddlebugs on the screen. Grover tells you how many you collected.
title: Grover's Number Rover

description:
Cookie Monster Letter Crunch is a 1-player educational game related to the alphabet.

Designed to teach young children letters and spelling by moving Cookie Monster to different positions to select a letter. There are 6 levels of difficulty for each activity.

  • Bake Away!: Words are displayed briefly, and then the player must spell it.
  • Easy Bake: Spell the word displayed on the screen
  • Chip Chase: Spell the displayed word, but the position of the letters keeps changing.
  • Chips Away!: Spell a briefly displayed. Letter positions keep changing.
title: Cookie Monster Letter Crunch

description:
Grobot is a 1-player arcade game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

The player controls Grobot, the galaxy gardener, and his harvester on the planet Kaldas. At the beginning of each session, the player is assigned weather conditions hot or cold and wet or dry. They then try to grow 4 of 16 different plants. Each plant prefers different weather conditions, and has different pest resistance. The more slowly a plant grows, the more it's worth when harvested. Plants begin to grow from the bottom of the screen, and they must be harvested when they reach the top and bloom. Verms live underground, and Grobot must descend from his harvester to scare away the Verm to prevent it from eating the crops. Gnats fly onto flowers and eat them, and can be scared away with the harvester.
title: Grobot

description:
Flip Side is a 1 - 2 player strategy game for the TRS-CoCo.

Players takes turns flipping pieces on a board, with the goal to claim as many positions as possible on the board. Each flip affects surrounding pieces, causing them to become flipped or unflipped. Players can define how many turns per rounds, and whether or not the players flip at the same time. Players also define what happens to surrounding pieces when a piece is flipped, causing the surrounding pieces to flip, be unflippable, or not change. The player with the most pieces at the end of the game is the winner.
title: Flip Side

description:
Roll-a-word is a 1-player educational game for the TRS-CoCo.

The player attempts to create sentences by rolling and matching words. At the beginning of each game, the player selects a sentence with words blanked out. The player then chooses from a number of different pictures, and must correctly spell that picture to insert it into the sentence. To spell a word, the player rolls the 1st and last 2 letters of the sentence. Animation and music accompany the activity
title: Roll-a-Word

description:
Star Trap is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the TRS-CoCo.

The player controls a small slow moving character in a maze. Their goal is to trap the rapidly moving star in a position where it cannot move. The player can drop a limited number of Xs, which block the star's passage. These are used to trap the star. The Xs can be picked back up again if needed, but each use of an X causes a loss of score. There are numerous gates, including: speed, jump, invisible, and magic. These affect character movement speed and the supply and effect of Xs. The game ends when the star has been captured. Players can create custom maps, where they define these parameters. The trapper has a limited time to end the game before all the diamonds around the edge of the screen disappear.
title: Star Trap

description:
Atom is an educational game to teach children about the elements.

The player controls a gravitron, which circles around the central atom on the screen. The central nucleus is surrounded by 2 spinning rings, an inner energy level and an outer barrier ring. The goal is to pick up stray electrons, and shoot them towards the spaces within the inner ring, so that they become a part of the atom. If the player shoots the barrier ring with an electron, the inner nucleus will explode. The player must hide behind a gravitron bunker in the corner of the screen to survive. The player starts with 3 gravitrons, and it's game over when they are lost. A countdown in nanoseconds tells the player how long they have left to create the required atoms. The player creates the first 52 elements.
title: Atom

description:
7 Card Stud is a graphical card game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

The player competes against 3 computer opponents in a game of 7 card stud. Cards are graphically displayed on the screen, and the players take turns calling, passing, or anteing. Gameplay is via joystick.
title: 7 Card Stud

description:
Gin Champion is a 1-player card game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

Contains 16 different versions of gin rummy at 10 different skill levels. Options include: Oklahoma Gin, Runs Around the Corner, Laying Off on Gin, and Spades Double. Cards are graphically displayed on the screen.
title: Gin Champion

description:
Star Blaze is a 1-player side-scrolling arcade game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

The player controls a patrol ship that can move in all directions, and fires directly forwards. The player must warp between 64 sectors to destroy all alien vessels. Played from a side view, the ship is armed with limited shields, fuel, and ammo. Certain sectors have repair or refuel stations, which the player can visit to recharge their vessel. A map at the bottom of the screen shows the location of alien vessels in each sector.

There are 8 levels of difficulty, and the player has 3 ships to complete their mission.
title: Star Blaze

description:
Space Assault is a 1-player Space Invaders clone for the TRS-80 CoCo.

The player controls a small ship on the bottom of the screen, that moves horizontally and fires vertically. The player tries to destroy numerous waves of alien invaders. The alien invaders move horizontally, while returning fire at the player. Each time an invader moves across the screen, they move down one row, and reverse direction. Several small shields offer protection for the player, but these are destroyed by alien and friendly fire. There are 2 levels of difficulty, and the player starts with 3 ships.
title: Space Assault

description:
Tennis is a 1 - 2 player arcade tennis game for the TRS-80 CoCo

Each player controls a character in a game of singles tennis. Play is is divided into games, sets, and matches, and players take turns serving. There are 2 levels of computer opponent.
title: Tennis

description:
Galactic Attack is a 1-player arcade game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

The player controls a small ship on the bottom of the screen that moves horizontally and fires vertically. The player encounters endless waves of 8 ships which shoot bombs towards the player, and dive at their position. The player must shoot down alien ships and avoid colliding with bombs or enemy vessels. The player starts with 3 ships, and gains a new one on level 3, level 8, and every 8th level thereafter.
title: Galactic Attack

description:
Card Games is a series of card games for the TRS-80 CoCo.

Contains graphical versions of Solitaire. Go Fish, Blackjack, War, Solo Poker, and Last Pirate.
title: Card Games

description:
Bridge Tutor 1 is a 1-player bridge game for the TRC-CoCo.

There are 100 unique hands, each teaching a unique offensive or defensive strategy. Cards are graphically displayed, and the player competes against 3 computer opponents.
title: Bridge Tutor 1

description:
Castle Guard is a1 - 2 player arcade game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

The estates of Lord Schmegley and Lord Dumschtuff have been feuding two decades, the point of dispute long forgotten. The continuing violence brought anguish and disruption to the entire kingdom and all who lived there. The good king could tolerate no more, and therefore commissioned the wizard Merlin to use his mystical wisdom to find a solution.

Colored smoke and roaring sounds billowed from Merlin's cave for a fortnight. Suddenly one midday, darkness befell the land. A flaming star burst forth from the cave's entrance. Behind this deadly fireball appeared Merlin, carrying two long magical pikes.

Each player controls a magical pike, as they try to bounce the fireball between the opposite sides of the screen. The pike can be moved in all directions, and if their castle is hit by a fireball, it takes damage. Two lakes, each in a corner of the screen, serve to slow the fireball by cooling it down. The battle continues until only one Lord has a castle left standing.
title: Castle Guard

description:
Castle of Tharoggad is a 1-player role-playing game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

For years the land of Tharoggad was ruled by a kindly Wizard. One terrible day the Good Wizard was abducted by his jealous evil brother and imprisoned in The Castle of Tharoggad. The Evil Wizard populated the castle with many horrible phantasms which solidify and attempt to kill any trespasser they encounter in the castle. He also set a few dangerous traps for any foolhardy adventurer who attempts to rescue the Good Wizard. As the bravest and strongest hero in the land, you are selected by the townspeople to enter the Castle of Tharoggad and save the Good Wizard.

Castle of Tharoggad is a colored mouse-driven version of Dungeons of Daggorath

All commands are via the movement, inventory, use, drop, and pick up buttons. The game contains five levels of dungeon to explore via a 1st person perspective, with more powerful monsters the deeper the player advances. Other features include monsters generating different sounds that grow louder or fainter as they get closer to the protagonist (even if they cannot be seen behind walls); and the real-time aspect of the heartbeat. If the player is injured or running too fast, his heart rate increases, and he may pass out if the player pushes too far. During that time, monsters keep moving and attacking.
title: Castle of Tharoggad

description:
Color Robot Battle is a 1 - 2 player educational programming game.

Two robots Alpha and Omega enter combat. Each robot is armed with missiles and lasers, and have separately operating turrets and tracks. The player must program the robot how to interact with their opponent in combat. Robots and turrets can point in 8 separate directions, and all movement, offensive, and defensive actions use up energy. The robots' energies are displayed as 2 bars on the bottom of the screen, and the first robot to lose all power is destroyed. Developed robots can be saved for future combat.
title: Color Robot Battle

description:
Crosswords is a 1 - 4 player word game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

Players create words for points similar to the board game Scrabble. There are 2 game modes:

  • Combination Mode: Create 1 new word per turn by using 7 letters selected by the computer and the existing words on the screen.
  • Single Play Mode: Try to create as many words as possible using 7 letters added to the existing words. Players starts with a blank board each turn.

Players can have 30, 60, 90 seconds, or unlimited time per turn.
title: Crosswords

description:
Desert Rider is a 1-player arcade game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

Test Tandy's all-terrain XR-2200 racer by taking it to its limit on a treacherous cross-desert race track. The player moves horizontally, and can accelerate and decelerate. The object is to complete each course as fast as possible, while avoiding rocks, holes, sharp turns, and other riders. After completing the fourth race, the three tracks become more difficult, and are selected at random. The player starts with a 3 crash allowance, and receives an additional allowance for each course finished. There are 3 levels of difficulty, and the game is over when the player runs out of crashes.
title: Desert Rider

description:
GFL Championship Football II is a sequel to GFL Championship Football only released for the TRS-80 CoCo.

Similar to the first-person perspective of earlier versions, the viewscreen has been reduced in size with a large overhead display of player positions on the right side of the screen. What you see is what the player sees – control and viewpoint passes from the kicker to the receiver on a punt or kickoff, and the quarterback to the running back or receiver on a pass or kick. Releasing passes involves rotating the controls to select the pass direction.

There are 28 fictional teams split into four divisions., and each is rated out of 3 on 8 areas of skill. Matches last for 4 quarters of either 4 or 7 minutes' in-play time. Menus to select plays or teams involve using diagonal movements for selection. Standard Gridiron rules apply – gain 10 yards in 4 attempts (downs) without fumbling or having a pass intercepted; or kick a punt or field goal.
title: GFL Championship Football II

description:
Radio Ball is a 1 - player pinball game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

Features a single pinball game. The player controls 2 flippers at the bottom of the screen, and they start with 5 balls.
title: Radio Ball

description:
Slay the Nereis is a 1-player Centipede clone for the TRS-80 CoCo.

You are the commander in charge of three mini-subs. During your mission, you soon discover that the area you were sent to scout is a dangerous one, teeming with several innocent looking creatures. Schools of fish, manta rays, starfish, jellyfish, and an occasional "Nereis", a marine creature which excretes a paralyzing poison.

The player controls a small sub at the bottom of the screen which can move in all directions, and partially up the screen. Numerous enemies stream towards the player, including schools of fish, which move laterally, and descend one level when they reach an obstruction. A new stage is reached by shooting all fish in the school.

The game is over when all subs are lost.
title: Slay the Nereis

description:
Avenger is a 1-player side-scrolling arcade game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

The player controls a small ship which moves vertically on the left side of the screen, as alien spacecraft approach from the right and fire at the player. A small map in the top right of the screen shows approaching vessels. The ship has unlimited laser blasts, and 3 bombs, which destroy all enemies on the screen. The player has 5 ships, and it's game over when all are lost.
title: Avenger

description:
Springster is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

Springster is the master of the Magnificent Maze! This maze, composed of 32 different planes, is filled with fabulous treasures, but is fraught with hidden dangers and deadly bad guys. The immensely valuable Maze Melon has been taken by the evil Maze Marauder, and placed in the lowest plane of the maze. Springster must recover the melon and return it to the highest level.

The player controls a spring, which can move in all directions on a maze, but can not move to levels that are too high or low. There are 8 total platform levels. On each level, the player has a limited amount of time to gather the displayed number of treasures. After this, the player must obtain a pot of gold and move it to a red square. This opens the purple square, which the player must land on to move to the next level. If the player is holding an emerald ring, and moves onto a red square, all enemies will temporarily become disoriented and move randomly. If the player moves onto a green square, they will kill all enemies on other green squares. After several uses, these squares turn black, and mean instant death. If the player is caught by an enemy, it's game over. Dark blue squares reveals special prizes, and light blue squares will make a player invisible if they are holding a candle.
title: Springster

description:
ZoneRunner is a 1-player real-time strategy trading game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

Looking into the vastness of space, you think about the galactic voyage ahead. You are a ZoneRunner, an interplanetary soldier of fortune, about to embark on your next mission. Your adventure entails flying your spacecraft among planets located in the outlying area of two closely situated galaxies. Your livelihood depends on buying and selling vitally-needed goods.

The player moves between planets buying and selling commodities to increase their wealth. To move between locations, the player selects the direction of movement and their engine power. Player location is shown on a galactic map with 3 levels of magnification. Upon arriving at different systems, the player can buy and sell commodities. Control of shields and weapons are also controlled by sliding bars, and these need to be replenished at systems.

As the player travels, they are at danger of attack by enemy vessels, which can steal the players goods.

If the player doesn't meet the needs of planets, the prices of commodities can go up, and planets can even die. As planets die, the player has to work harder to supply needs. When all planets die, it's game over.
title: ZoneRunner

description:
Death Trap is a 1-player tank game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

The player navigates a tank through a very large maze, trying to reach the end point. The player is constantly chased by a pulsating square, which can move through walls, and destroys the player on touch. The maze is riddled with a number of items: Destructo mines which destroy the player, hyperspace mines which teleport the player, mapping squares, extra tanks, extra fuel, and random items that could be any of the above. Every move uses fuel, and this must be regularly refilled. The player has 3 lives, and it's game over when all are gone.
title: Death Trap

description:
Catalyst is a 1-player action game based around organic chemistry for the TRS-80 CoCo

The player controls a small 4-pronged cursor that moves in all directions. Free carbon and hydrogen atoms and a catalyst bounce about the screen, and the player tries to capture and link hydrogen and carbon atoms together. Each carbon atoms can form 4 bonds. If a free atom crashes into the cursor at a bad location, the player loses a life. If a free atom crashes into the enlarging molecule, the struck sections are destroyed. On each level, the player must make a progressively larger molecule, while avoiding more free moving atoms. The player has a limited time each level, and has a total of 3 lives. When the molecule is complete, the player must capture the bouncing catalyst.
title: Catalyst

description:
A Mazing World of Malcolm Mortar is a 1-player arcade game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

As an apprentice bricklayer, you must carry loads of bricks and dynamite. Suddenly, you feel a searing pain in your head, and everything goes black. You awaken to a myriad of passages filled with monsters.

The player controls a small character who must move through a maze to reach the exit to the next level. The player is armed with dynamite, which is dropped to blow up enemies and weak walls. As the player is attacked by monsters, they lose bricks, but can pick up more in the maze. Some exits are locked, and the player must discover a specific route to the exit to open the door. The player can construct walls to protect themselves from enemies, but certain enemies can chew through these. The player has a single life, and it's game over if eaten by an enemy.
title: A Mazing World of Malcolm Mortar

description:
Intercept 4 is a 1 - 2 player arcade game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

The player tries to rescue colonists stranded on an alien planet. Gameplay features 2 components. The player starts by attempting to land their ship at a colonies alpha to omega. This is done from a first person perspective, and they must shoot down approaching alien vessels. After landing at a colony, the player navigates the individual colony trying to find colonists. The player starts with 2000 colonists to rescue, but as they fly past colonies or are shot in space, the surviving colonists are reduced. The player has 3 ships with limited energy, which can be shot down while in orbit.
title: Intercept 4

description:
Space Intruders is a 1-player Space Invaders game for the TRS-80 CoCo.

The player controls a small ship that moves laterally at the bottom of the screen and fires vertically forwards. The player must destroy waves of attacking aliens, which move horizontally across the screen, reach the edge, move down, and reverse direction. The player must avoid alien fire, and destroy all enemy aliens before they reach the bottom of the screen. The player starts with 3 lives, and shields offer temporary protection for the player.

sample_screenshots.caption: Title screen with an animated starfield at the background.

title: Space Intruders

description:
Rupert Rhythm is a 1-player arcade game for the TRS-80 CoCo.
